hopobject.body:
Doesn't open source software deserve open source hardware?

BeagleBone Black is true open source hardware with every part available through everyday distributors in quantity one. The BeagleBoard.org Foundation is a non-profit and charges no royalties for the design materials, all released under open licenses. Based on a super-scalar ARMv7 processor core with ARM-standard vector processing extensions running at 1GHz, BeagleBone Black fits in a mint tin and enables open source software developers to show off without breaking their power budget---or their piggy bank. Now at only $45 through distributors world-wide, shouldn't you be showing off on BeagleBone Black too?

If you are interested in advancing the state of Fedora on BeagleBone Black, let's talk! E-mail jkridner at beagleboard dot org.

Let's code!

The BeagleBone Black experience

BeagleBone Black is a great way for developers who program for the web to get a first taste of hardware---and for many hardware hackers to get a first taste of Linux. To bridge these communities, it is important to have a solid first experience.

Elements of the desired experience

  • Web-based IDE - Cloud9 ships with the boards today, but the Adafruit IDE and codebender.cc solutions look very interesting.
  • BoneScript - A JavaScript library built on node.js along with the bone101 tutorial that utilizes remote procedure calls within the browser to become interactive, minimizing the effort to go from web programming to physical interactions with all sorts of sensors and actuators.
  • Python - The Adafruit Python library is rapidly growing along with libraries of demos on how to get started with physical computing in a popular first (and sometimes last) language.
  • gcc, make, autotools, OpenCV, pkg-config and a bunch of libraries - Building simple applications in C/C++ should be simple!
  • real-time patches - Not yet shipping in all distros, real-time performance is a critcal aspect for building physically interactive devices.
  • Networking and file storage over USB - You shouldn't need to buy extra hardware to get started; everything in the box should be enough and it should be as self-documenting as possible.
